content.text: The best way to learn is by doing. Now that you have a foundational understanding of the key concepts and tools, it's time to start building your own automations. Start with simple projects and gradually work your way up to more complex ones.

content.alt: A person planning a project on a whiteboard

content.text: Description: Create a simple CRM to keep track of your personal and professional contacts.

items: A form to add new contacts (e.g., Tally, Jotform)
Automatically add new contacts to an Airtable base
Send a follow-up email to new contacts
Set reminders to follow up with contacts

content.text: Description: Create a system to automatically post content to your social media accounts.

items: An Airtable base to store your content ideas
A view in Airtable to show content that is ready to be published
An automation that posts content to your social media accounts at a scheduled time

content.text: Description: Create a system to automatically generate and send invoices to clients.

items: An Airtable base to store your client and project information
A button in Airtable to trigger the invoicing process
An automation that generates an invoice and sends it to the client
An automation that marks the invoice as paid when the client pays

content.text: Description: Create a system that automatically finds and shares articles relevant to your interests.

items: Use Feedly to subscribe to your favorite blogs and news sources
Use OpenAI to summarize the articles
Use Zapier/Make to post the summarized articles to your social media accounts

content.question: Which of the following is NOT a good practice when starting a new automation project?
options: Starting with a small, simple project
Breaking the project down into smaller tasks
Trying to build a large, complex automation from the start
Asking for help from online communities
content.answer: Trying to build a large, complex automation from the start

items: Start small: Don't try to build a massive, complex automation on your first try. Start with something simple and build on it over time.
Break it down: Break down your project into smaller, manageable tasks. This will make it less overwhelming and easier to troubleshoot.
Don't be afraid to ask for help: There are many online communities and forums where you can get help with your automation projects.
